Buster Scruggs.Action: Sings cheerfully to his horse and addresses the camera with a friendly and genial tone.
Dismisses the negative nickname 'The Misanthrope' for himself, stating he doesn't hate his fellow man even when they are tiresome or surly.
Acknowledges that expecting better from people who cheat or are surly is foolish, showing tolerance for human flaws.
Maintains a clean and composed appearance, confidently sings while riding alone through the vast and monotonous landscape, and speaks directly and engagingly to the audience.
Acknowledge receiving a negative nickname 'The Misanthrope' but intellectually disputes it, showing self-awareness and emotional control.
Relies on music and humor to keep morale high during solitary travel, demonstrating adaptive coping skills.
Dismissively tosses away the wanted poster with his negative label without showing concern, which could hint at overconfidence or underestimating consequences.
Addresses bartender and other patrons with a pleasant demeanor despite knowing he is violating laws, indicating a good-natured and sincere attitude.
Responds to a taunt with a smile and witty rebuke, showing confidence without hostility and maintaining composure.
Quickly kills a man who provokes him after verbal sparring, using deadly violence in a cold and decisive manner.
Confidently enters a hostile environment, calmly engages with rough men and a bartender, and handles a provocation with witty verbal repartee.
Effortlessly draws and shoots the offending hard man swiftly and skillfully, demonstrating superior gunmanship under pressure.
Winks at the bartender before shooting and acknowledges his sloppy shooting allowing a man to survive.
Leaves the wounded man to crawl away alone into the desert with no aid.
Sings a lonesome song while riding away, showing a touch of lightheartedness and camaraderie with his audience.
Draws and shoots the hard man instantly and efficiently.
Quickly fends off multiple opponents with precise shots.
Maintains calm and confident posture after the shooting, using a quirky gun hold and eye contact to disarm the bartender.
Fails to kill the last man, recognizing and admitting his sloppy shooting.
Demonstrates situational awareness by evaluating the environment and making a reasoned decision to leave, considering remoteness and threats.
Casually sings and seems relaxed immediately after a deadly shootout, indicating emotional control.
Amiably respects house policy by unhitching guns without complaint, making light conversation with the checker.
Politely asks to take a spot at the poker table after a player leaves.
Refuses to play a hand of cards he has already seen despite pressure and threat of violence.
Holds hands away from his sides as a sign he is unarmed, indicates non-aggressive intent.
Politely requests the surly man to place his weapon in the receptacle, appeals to local norms.
Uses lethal force against the surly man after the man aims his gun at him.
Acknowledges he is not devious by nature, but justifies his violent tactics when unarmed.
Joins in raucous song with saloon patrons, seems jovial and inclusive.

Clarifies he doesn't shoot anyone in the back and implies the dead gambler was suicidal, showing some honesty but little empathy.
Loses smile briefly when identified but recovers it, using humor to defuse tension.
Smiles at Ike before the duel, uses friendly language like 'pardner'.
Shoots off all of Ike's fingers and thumb, causing severe injury without apparent hesitation.
Displays casual, almost playful demeanor while disabling Ike, including joking about missing with his last bullet.
Kills Ike without hesitation, shows no remorse at the moment.
Smiles and offers genuine praise to the young singer, calling the voice 'mighty sweet' and acknowledging the compliment.
Reflects on the violence and the cycle of proving oneself with a tone of sadness and introspection.
Uses humor (mirror joke) immediately after killing, indicating some detachment or lack of solemnity.
Quickly shoots Ike who threatens him with a gun, showing decisive action and marksmanship.
Uses the mirror as a prop for a pun and reflects on the situation, indicating cleverness and presence of mind.
Immediately reloads and prepares for the next confrontation calmly and confidently.
Expresses some doubt or hesitation about entering the undertaking business and wearing a black suit, showing internal conflict or reluctance.
Sings peacefully with another cowboy, expresses hope for a better afterlife free of meanness and unfairness, wishes to reunite and sing sweet songs together
Robs a bank by force, shoots at the teller, takes money and escapes.
Protects himself cautiously after the robbery, stays alert to threats.
Wields shotgun effectively, wearing pot and pans armor for protection and offense.
Successfully disarms opponent by shooting his shoulder, causing gun to fall.
Refuses to give his horse to any of the posse members despite their request after being sentenced to death.
Tries to calm his horse amid chaotic battle, remains physically engaged despite panic.
Declines to give away his horse to posse members, showing assertiveness and independence.
Appears anxious and awkward on his horse, rolling his eyes around at the battle.
No direct actions or statements from Buster Scruggs are present in this excerpt; the excerpt focuses on other characters and a separate cowboy being processed for hanging.
Gives the terrified condemned man next to him a somewhat patronizing smile and asks 'First time?'
Carefully pans for gold with deliberate, skilled motions, methodically washing soil and inspecting for gold specks.
Pauses periodically to observe and confirm environmental stability before proceeding, indicating thoughtful caution.
Does not show overt excitement or distraction after finding gold, maintaining calm focus.
Carefully pans for gold by methodically digging and washing along the stream, marking holes with straw to track effort and results.
Digs multiple holes in a systematic pattern, showing perseverance and planning to locate the richest gold spots.
Rises stiff and removes gold by carelessly washing it away back into the stream.

Displays no attempt to aid or express remorse for the defeated opponent.
Calmly prepares and smokes a cigarette after shooting the prospector, displaying composure and confidence.
Attempts to drop into the hole holding his gun above his head, showing tactical thinking to maintain weapon readiness.
Loses balance and fires gun uncontrollably in the confined space after the prospector grabs his ankle, indicating loss of control.
Tangles physically with the prospector but fails to maintain control of his gun, which is wrested away.
Raises his free hand to shield his face but is shot through the hand and killed, demonstrating insufficient defensive response.
Successfully aims and shoots multiple targets during an intense Indian charge, displaying calm and accurate marksmanship under pressure.
Takes a confident and commanding stance despite numerous incoming fire and a chaotic environment.
Quickly adapts to changing circumstances, shifting targets and pursuing downed enemy effectively.

Calmly disarms and neutralizes a man aiming a gun at him by using quick thinking and precise actions to manipulate the environment (stamping on the table to force the man's hand to fire into his own face).
Uses knowledge of local rules and norms to try to de-escalate the threat before violence.
Displays calm acceptance of mortality and reflects philosophically on life and afterlife while harmonizing with another singer.
Does not resist or attempt to change his fate even at death, instead transitions into a peaceful, spiritual state.
Remains calm and attempts to soothe his panicked horse with verbal commands 'Whoa... easy...'.
Is portrayed as noosed and helpless during the battle, unable to intervene or escape, eventually having his throat cinched tighter by his horse's motion.
